courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Introduction to Actuarial Computing Using Prophet
courses.description: Prophet is one of the most popular actuarial software to help actuaries on their daily work. This course introduces students with actuarial computing using Prophet for life and non-life insurance products. Topics include: introduction to Prophet and Data Conversion System (DCS), and modelling life and non-life insurance products via Prophet.

3. 建立负债产品及解决设计产品时所衍生的问题

3. 透过 Prophet 进行运算及分析结果

4. 介绍 Data Conversion System (DCS)

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Non-life Actuarial Models
courses.description: This course discusses probabilistic and statistical techniques that deal with non-life actuarial models.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: FINA2220 or STAT2001 or permission from instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the completion of this course, students should be familiar with the following about general insurance modelling:
Frequency and loss distributions and their estimation, aggregate loss model, risk measure, extreme value distribution, credibility theory.
Students would also be familiar with the related implementation techniques for the calibration and evaluation of models using Excel spreadsheet.

修畢本科之後，學生會熟知下列關於非壽險數學模型之知識：
頻率與損失分佈與其估量、整體損失模型、風險值、極值分佈、可信度理論。
學生亦會熟知利用 Excel 試算表做模型校準與評價之技巧。

• Gray and Pitts, 2012. Risk Modeling in General Insurance: From Principles to Practice, Cambridge University Press.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Advanced Short-term Actuarial Mathematics
courses.description: This course develops the student's knowledge of the advanced theories of actuarial models and the application of those models to short-term insurance. Applications include: coverage modifications of short-term insurance products, construction and selection of parametric models, pricing using credibility models, pricing and reserving of short-term insurance coverages.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: FINA3222 or permission from instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, the students should be able to: understand the characteristics of and uses for commonly used severity, frequency, and aggregate models; perform parametric and non-parametric estimation; understand the concepts of credibility; and calculate premiums and reserves for short-term insurance coverages.

完成科目後，學員應該能夠： 了解常用的嚴重性、頻率和聚合模型的特點和用途； 執行參數和非參數估計； 了解可信度的概念； 併計算短期保險的保費和準備金。
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Severity, Frequency and Aggregate Models
- Methods of creating new severity distriubtions; comparsion of severity distributions; the (a,b,1) class distributions; mixture distributions; convolution and recursive formulas; discretizing a continuous distribution; aggregate deductible
2. Coverage Modifications
- Evaluation of the effect of coverage modifications
3. Construction and Selection of Parametric Models
- Maximum likelihood estimation; Bayesion estimation; model selection
4. Credibility
- Bayesian credibility; Buhlmann and Buhlmann-Straub models; empirical Bayesian method
5. Pricing and Reserving
- Estimation of unpaid losses and IBNR; methods for projecting lossess; rate changes; risk classification

1. 嚴重性、頻率和聚合模型
- 創建新的嚴重性分佈的方法； 嚴重性分佈的比較； (a,b,1) 類分佈； 混合物分佈； 卷積和遞歸公式； 離散化連續分佈； 累計免賠額
2. 覆蓋範圍修改
- 評估覆蓋修改的效果
3. 參數模型的構建與選擇
- 最大似然估計； 貝葉斯估計； 型號選擇
4. 信譽
- 貝葉斯可信度； Buhlmann 和 Buhlmann-Straub 模型； 經驗貝葉斯方法
5. 定價和計算準備金
- 估計未付損失和 IBNR； 預測損失的方法； 費率變化； 風險分類

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Applications of Risk Models
courses.description: This course discusses risk models for pricing and valuation of multiple life, health insurance and general insurance.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Research Project in Insurance, Financial and Actuarial Analysis
courses.description: A student may enroll on this special directed study of selected topics in insurance, finance, and/or actuarial science with the permission and under the supervision of an instructor. The content of the course will depend on the research plans of the student. A written report should be submitted for evaluation, and a final presentation to members of the Department of Finance should be made at the end of the project.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students should be about to (i) understand the purpose of researching and conduct research individually; (ii) write a literature review on a research topic; (iii) apply the appropriate methodology on relevant data set to support their new findings.
學生完成本科後應該能夠(i)明白研究目的及獨立進行一些研究課題；(ii)對某個研究題目撰寫文獻背景撮要及(iii)採集相關數據及應用適合之研究方法去支持其研究成果。
courses.course_syllabus:
This course emphasizes in developing students’ research ability. Students taking this course will conduct research on a topic in insurance, finance, and/or actuarial science under the supervision of an instructor.
本科着重於發展學生的研究能力。學生將會在導師指導下，對一個關於保險、財務或精算課題進行深入研究。

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Derivatives for Actuaries II
courses.description: This course is a continuation of FINA3250 and aims to provide students with knowledge in derivatives and their applications in pricing and reserving insurance products. Topics include Greek letters; dynamic hedging; exotic options; interest rate models including the Black-Derman-Toy model and continuous-time equilibrium models; Monte-Carlo simulation; variance reduction; and actuarial applications of derivatives such as equity-linked insurance, guaranteed minimum death benefit and guaranteed annuity option.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: FINA2210, 2220 and 3250.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course aims to
(i) study the principle of dynamic hedging, and
(ii) explore analytic and numerical techniques in the valuation of derivatives including plain vanilla options, exotic options, interest rate options and multivariate options.
After following FINA4280, students are expected to be familiar with the following about rational valuation of derivative securities:
• the principle of dynamic hedging
• the multivariate Black-Scholes model and change of numéraire
• valuation and uses of exotic options
• the Black’s model for bond options
• discrete- and continuous-time interest rate models, including the binomial tree, Vasicek and Cox-Ingersoll-Ross model
• Monte-Carlo simulation
本科旨在探討：
(1) 動態對沖，及
(2) 分析法和數值法在衍生工具 (包括一般期權、奇異期權、利率期權及多元期權) 定價中之應用。
完成FINA4280的學生將熟習以下關於衍生工具合理定價之原則：
• 動態對沖之原理
• 多元畢蘇模型與單位資產之轉換
• 奇異期權之定價及應用
• 債券期權畢氏模型
• 離散及連續時間利率模型，包括二項式模型、Vasicek 及CIR模型
• 蒙地卡羅模擬法
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) Greek letters and dynamic hedging:
Greek letters, delta-hedging, discrete hedging error, gamma neutrality
(2) The multivariate Black-Scholes model:
Commodity assets, multivariate geometric Brownian motion, the concept of numéraire, change of numéraire
(3) Exotic options:
Valuation of the following exotic options: exchange, barrier, compound, currency-linked options and Asian options
(4) Interest rate processes:
Binomial interest rate tree, Black’s model, term structure equation for interest rate derivatives, one-factor continuous-time equilibrium models, including the Vasicek and Cox-Ingersoll-Ross model
(5) Simulation:
Simulation of normal random variates, Monte-Carlo valuation of European derivatives, variance reduction methods including stratified sampling, antithetic variate and control variate method
(6) Actuarial applications of derivatives:
Equity-linked life insurance, guaranteed minimum death benefit and guaranteed annuity options
(1) 希臘字母與動態對沖：
希臘字母，delta-對沖，離散時間對沖誤差，gamma-對沖。
(2) 多元畢蘇模型：
商品資產，多元幾何布朗運動，單位資產之概念和轉換。
(3) 奇異期權：
以下奇異期權之定價及應用: 交換期權、障礙期權、復合期權、外幣掛鈎期權及亞式期權。
(4) 利率過程：
二項式利率樹模型，畢氏模型，利率衍生工具之利率期限結構方程式，單因子連續時間均衡模型，包括Vasicek 及CIR模型。
(5) 模擬法：
正態隨機變數之模擬，應用蒙地卡羅法估計歐式期權的價值，降低變異數技術，包括分層隨機抽樣、對偶變數及控制變量。
(6) 衍生工具在精算學之應用：
股票掛鈎人壽保險、最低死亡保證給付、保證年金選擇權。

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Actuarial Internship
courses.description: Internship experience in actuarial departments of insurance and related companies for more than five months. A written report should be submitted for evaluation.
courses.learning_outcomes:
To let students have exposure to the practical environment other than learning in class. Such experience will greatly enhance the quality of education provided by the university and improve our students’ competitiveness in the job market.

本科主要讓同學到實際的工作環境實習。這種在課堂以外學習的經驗可大大提高大學教育的素質及增強學生們在職場上的競爭力。
courses.course_syllabus:
Major actuarial concepts and topics, such as product development; pricing; valuation and marketing, will be covered via internship experience.

學生將於精算部門實習期間，獲取產品設計、定價、儲備計算及市場推廣等主要精算概念。
courses.feedback_evaluation:
CTE questionnaires
Reflection of instructors
Reflection of supervisors
courses.required_readings: Not applicable. No reading is needed because this actuarial internship course provides a student with hands-on experience of what an actual job in an actuarial department would be like. It targets at bridging formal university education and work life, the integration and synthesis of subject knowledge, and the development of interpersonal and communication skills. After the completion of more than five months full time in the actuarial department of insurance and related companies, students are required to submit a written report and do a presentation with their real life working experience for evaluation.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: China Banking and Financial System
courses.description: This course provides students with a basic understanding of the banking and financial system of China. Issues to be discussed include the nature of banking in China, corporate governance and regulatory framework, similarities and differences between China's banking structure and structures elsewhere in the world, credit market developments, as well as recent developments and trends. Important current issues will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The primary objective of this course is to provide an introduction to the framework of banking and financial system of China. At the end of the semester, students are expected to be able to:

~ have an overview of the banking industry and financial system
~ identify the key functions of banking system
~ understand the major controversial issues of the banking industry and financial system
~ understand the possible directions of regulatory reforms in China

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: China Equity Securities Market
courses.description: This course provides students with a basic understanding of the equity markets of China. Issues to be discussed include China's markets for securities, corporate governance and regulatory framework, ownership structure, trading mechanisms, price behavior and efficiency, as well as recent developments and trends. Important current issues will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The primary objective of this course is to provide an introduction to the framework of equity markets in China. At the end of the semester, students are expected to be able to:

~ have an overview of the equity markets in the financial system
~ identify the key functions of equity markets
~ understand the major controversial issues of equity markets
~ understand the possible directions of regulatory reforms and developments of equity markets in China
courses.course_syllabus:
| Topic | Contents |
| --- | --- |
| 1. Brief history of China equity securities market | China equity securities markets in Qin dynasty and ROC-era, Development of equity market in PRC economic reform |
| 1. Equity primary markets | IPO listing and pricing procedures, Ownership structure of companies pre-listing and post-listing, Delisting of sub-standard companies |
| 1. Equity secondary markets | Introduction of market participants - exchanges, brokers and other intermediaries, Trading mechanisms in stock exchanges, Electronic trading and direct-market-access (DMA), Margin trading and securities lending |
| 1. Laws and regulations | Securities Law of the PRC, Regulatory processes, Corporate governance, Bankruptcy resolution and creditors’ rights, Anti-money-laundering (AML) regulations, Tax policy, Investor protection and education |
| 1. Market infrastructure | Omnibus and segregated account structures, Equity settlement system, Financial news and data services, Chinese equity indices |
| 1. Market access and Stock Connect | QFII and RQFII, Stock Connect with HKEx |

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Structured Products: Fundamentals and Analysis
courses.description: This course introduces students to the wide array of structured products in the financial market. It will begin with an introduction of exotic derivatives, followed by detailed discussions on popular structured products in different asset classes, structuring rationales of the products, and the typical transaction cycle in banks. Students finishing the course are expected to be able to identify the risk and return on similar products in the market and make fair judgments on recent issues related to structured products.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The primary objective of this course is to provide an introduction to the theories and practices of structured products in financial markets. At the end of the semester, students are expected to be able to:

~ have basic knowledge of the market convention and trading mechanisms of structured products
~ understand the concepts behind sophisticated analytical tools and techniques
~ understand the return-risk characteristics of structured products
~ understand related technical publications and how to construct a portfolio using them
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic
Content
1. Overview of structured product business
- Participants in structured product market
- Building blocks of structured products
- Basics of volatility surface
2. Listed structured products
- ETN
- L&I ETF
- CBBC
- Warrant
3. Over-the-counter structured products
- ELN, CLN
- PPN
- Accumulator
- Autocallable
- TARN
4. Risk recycling products
- Single stock dispersion
- Corridor variance swap
- Covariance swap
- Dividend future/swap
- Volatility products on VT underlying

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Bond Markets: Analysis and Strategies
courses.description: This course aims to introduce to students the basic market convention and trading mechanisms of the bond market. With the help from real-time market quotes from Bloomberg and/or Reuters, a real-life bond portfolio management project will be utilized to further polish students' fixed income portfolio management skills. This course builds on students' previous knowledge on concepts of duration and convexity. Deeper analyses will be done in the portfolio context, e.g. Barbell, Bullet and ladder strategies. In the exercises, the students will manage their bond portfolio against a Merrill Lynch 5-yr UST Index.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The primary objective of this course is to provide an introduction to the theories and practices of fixed income securities. At the end of this semester, students are expected to be able to:

~ have a basic understanding of the market convention and trading mechanisms of the bond market
~ construct and manage a real-life bond portfolio by using data retrieved from Bloomberg and Reuters
~ have an in-depth understanding of the strategies such as barbell, bullet and ladder
~ evaluate the performance of their portfolio against that of a benchmark chosen

This course builds on students' previous knowledge on concepts of duration and credit rating. Deeper analyses will be done in the portfolio context, e.g. market risk and liquidity risk. In the exercises, the students will manage their bond portfolio against a Merrill Lynch 5-yr UST Index.

With the help from real-time market quotes from Bloomberg and/or Reuters, projects based on real-life trading strategies will be utilized to further polish students' understanding in the world of derivative securities. Deeper analyses will be done in the portfolio risk management context.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The primary objective of this course is to provide an introduction to the theories and practices of financial trading. At the end of the semester, students are expected to be able to:

- have a basic understanding of the market convention and trading mechanisms of the financial market
- construct and manage a real-life portfolio by using data retrieved from Bloomberg and Reuters
- have an in-depth understanding of the strategies involved in arbitrage and hedging
- evaluate the performance of their portfolio against that of a benchmark chosen
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction to Trading: Markets in Practice

- Introduction to Futures: Specifications and Strategies

- Market Making: Trading Implied Volatility

- Market Making: Position Adjustment Quoting

CTE questionnaires

Reflection of instructors

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Behavioral Finance
courses.description:
Traditional finance seeks to understand financial markets assuming that investors are “rational.” Rationality means that investors can access to and have the ability to process information correctly and that competition between investors ensures that securities are correctly priced to reflect all available information. That is, the market is efficient. However, recent studies suggest that markets are not efficient and that investors are not fully rational. For example, particular trading strategies based on past information such as past returns and accounting information are able to outperform the markets. In addition, studies find that investors are committed to certain heuristic-based biases and frame dependent such as overconfidence, optimism, self-attribution, illusion of control, loss aversion, representativeness heuristic, anchoring, availability, ambiguity aversion, hindsight, flaming, etc. Behavioral biases combined with limits to arbitrage may result in securities not to be correctly priced.
This course will help students understand how individuals’ attitudes and behaviors affect their financial decisions and financial markets. In the practical side, this course will emphasize the role of investors’ psychological biases on various types of market inefficiency and show that how sophisticated investors can take advantage of these behavioral biases. This is a research oriented course with emphasis on both psychology theories and data analysis skills.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Pre-requisite: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
2. Not for students who have taken ECON4470
courses.course_syllabus:
No. Topics
I Introduction
Foundation I: Expected Utility Theory and its Violations
(Group Formation)
II Foundation II: Investor Psychology and Behavioral Biases
- Heuristics Biases
- Frame Dependence
- Overconfidence and Attribution Biases
- Inattention
III Foundation III: Market Efficiency and Challenge to Market Efficiency
- Efficient Market Hypothesis Revisited
- Asset Pricing Anomalies Driven by Psychological Biases
- Limits to Arbitrage
- Disagreement
IV Data Mining Workshop I: Programming with Trading Strategies
V Behavioral Corporate Finance I: Mergers and Acquisitions
VI Data Mining Workshop II: Event Studies of Corporate Events & Search Techniques of Corporate Information
VII Behavioral Corporate Finance II: IPOs and SEOs
VIII Presentation of Group Projects
courses.feedback_evaluation: There will be two anonymous evaluations within the semester to collect feedback from students. At the end of the semester, students will particulate the CUHK course and teaching evaluation.

The following three main reference books are very useful for this course.
1. Lucy F. Ackert & Richard Deaves, 2010, Behavioral Finance: Psychology, Decision-Making, and Markets, South-Western Cengage Learning: USA
2. Hersh Shefrin, 2002, Beyond Greed and Fear, Oxford University Press: UK
3. Daniel Kaheman, 2013, Thinking Fast and Slow, Farrar, Straus and Giroux: USA
courses.recommended_readings:

2. Thomas Gilovich, Dale W. Griffin, and Daniel Kahneman (Ed.), Heuristics and Biases: The Psychology of Intuitive Judgment, Cambridge University Press: USA
3. John R. Nofsinger, The Psychology of Investing, Prentice Hall Press: USA

courses.title: Current developments in FinTec

meetings.instructor: Dr. LAM Full Yet Eric Campbell
Dr. LAM Full Yet Eric Campbell
Dr. LAM Full Yet Eric Campbell
Dr. LAM Full Yet Eric Campbell

courses.description:
The advancement of technology is changing the global banking and financial industry. Using a variety of case studies, this course will look into the recent developments and emerging trends in financial technology (FinTech), and how they are affecting the various segments of financial services, such as payments, lending, trade finance, insurance, asset management, etc.

In addition, this course will also cover specific topics such as applications of blockchain in finance, initial coin offerings, crowdfunding, tokenization and valuation of digital currencies. Examples from start-up companies will be used to illustrate these concepts, so that students will gain a holistic view of the FinTech ecosystem.

To obtain relevant practical experience, students will be required to work on a group project where they will analyse the competitiveness of a FinTech company and recommend forward looking business strategies. Possible attachment to a Hong Kong-based FinTech start-up firm will be encouraged.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: FINA2010 or FINA2310 or permission from instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
•Understand the drivers for the FinTech industry and their current and future impact on global banking and finance
•Understand how the major business segments in finance are being affected by technological advancement
•Understand the opportunities that FinTech may bring to the financial industry
•Acquire basic industry, financial, and entrepreneurial knowledge and skills to evaluate the competitiveness and viability of FinTech companies
•Using acquired knowledge and skills to potentially develop a business plan for a FinTech start-up
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to the FinTech industry
2. Key Drivers of FinTech
3. Payment and Lending
4. Distributed Ledger and Digital Currency
5. WealthTech and InsurTech
6. Big Data and Artificial Intelligence
7. Initial Coin Offering (ICO) and Crowdfunding
8. Tokenization
9. Cryptoasset valuation model
10. Fundraising and Financing for FinTech
courses.feedback_evaluation: At the end of the course, students will be required to complete a survey for the CUHK Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE).
courses.required_readings:
No textbook is required.

All reading materials will be emailed to students from time to time. They will be relevant for class topics. All exam questions will come from class lectures and emailed reading materials. We will also discuss current events in Fintech as they hit the news at each lecture. Students are encouraged to share interested readings.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Financial Markets from a Macro Perspective
courses.description: This is a financial economics course which analyses global financial markets from a macro perspective. Real life cases will be discussed and emphasis will be placed on using data analysis and charting tools to evaluate and present economic and financial.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: FINA3020 or FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, students are expected to:

1. Have a holistic view of the key components of the global economy and current trends, and understand how these trends affect financial markets.

2. Know where to find important and useful economic and financial data, and how to analyze and present this information effectively to a general audience.

3. Acquire theoretical as well as practical financial market knowledge to evaluate the outlook of different asset classes and geographic regions, and to develop investment ideas.
courses.required_readings:
1. "Macroeconomics" by Abel, Bernanke, and Croushore (10th edition, 2020), published by Pearson.

2. Relevant articles and papers published by major financial institutions will be used throughout the course, they include (but not limited to): The International Monetary Fund (IMF), J.P. Morgan Asset Management, HSBC, Invesco, The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), The World Bank, The Economist, Brookings Institution, etc.
courses.recommended_readings: Apart from the three reference books listed above, relevant reading materials, lecture notes and exercises will also be posted on Blackboard.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Computerized Trading and Big Data
courses.description: Computerized trading and big data have rapidly changed the financial industry in recent years. The course will cover methodology and topics of computerized trading and innovations in the area of big data. Computerized trading will be the first part of the course. It will introduce the continuous electronic limit order book and extend to auctions, dealers, and dark trading mechanisms. The course will examine informational efficiency, measurement of liquidity, and empirical analysis of price discovery. It will cover current topics in regulation and high-frequency trading. Big data in finance will be the second part of the course. Students will learn how to overcome three dimensions of challenges in big data: large size, high dimension, and complex structure.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes: After completion of the course, student should be able to gain the latest perspective on different financial issues and topics.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Financial Management
courses.description: This offering provides an overview and analysis of financial decision-making within the corporate setting. Various facets of financial management are tackled from both theoretical and applied perspectives. Key topic areas include capital budgeting, the concept of risk and expected returns, valuation of stocks and bonds, capital structure theory and its applications, cost of capital, corporate dividend policy, working capital management and equity fund-raising methods.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA (Chinese); or MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or Master of Accountancy
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to understand essential characteristics of securities, structure of local equity markets, and the predominance of Chinese State-owned Enterprise companies. Students will be able to know the importance of equity and debt markets, as well as corporate dividend and gearing (leverage) policies. Students will get familiar with the properties of derivative securities and their role in hedging risk within corporate/ financial management context.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Foundational concepts: cash flows, and time value of money
- Discounted cash flow and multiples-based valuation methods
- Investment evaluation criteria, and process of capital budgeting
- Stock and bond characteristics, and valuation
- Risk, return, portfolio, diversification, and CAPM
- Cost of capital
- Capital structure and payout policy
- IPOs

courses.title: Fundamentals of Sustainable Finance
courses.description: The course aims to provide students with the knowledge and understanding of climate change risks and opportunities and their impact on capital markets. Topics will cover circular economy, core climate-economic theory and the role of central banks and supervisory authorities, climate change and equity investment opportunities, climate change risk management. An in-depth understanding of the impact of climate risks on asset allocation and the practical skills of portfolio alignment to a low-carbon economy will also be included.

Students will be able to appreciate external fund-raising activities through equity and debt markets, as well as corporate dividend and gearing (leverage) policies. courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Capital Markets and Corporate Financing in Greater China
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the capital markets and financial institutions in the Greater China (China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan), and financing strategies for corporations in this region, specific topics include stock markets, bond markets financial intermediaries, capital raising strategies and mergers and acquisitions. Emphasis will be made on how the Greater China's different institutional factors impact the functioning of the financial markets and institutions, and in turn the financing strategies of corporations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA (Chinese)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to apply the fundamental financial concepts and tools to the financing and payout decisions faced by a firm in the Greater China area.
Students will be able to evaluate different methods of going public and pick the optimal approach for their companies.
Students will be able to assess the risk profile of firms; specifically, estimate the costs of capital, including debt and equity capital, using financial data.
Students are also expected to understand the structures of different capital markets in China: the equity market, the bond market and the financial assets traded in each of these markets.

courses.description: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is being used in the financial services industry worldwide. Financial institutions and Financial Technologies (FinTech) start-ups are using AI methods to assess credit quality, to price and market insurance contracts, and to automate client interaction. Some of these companies are optimising scarce capital with AI and machine learning techniques, as well as back-testing models and analysing the market impact of trading large positions. Hedge funds, broker-dealers, and other firms are using AI to find signals for higher (and uncorrelated) returns and optimise trading execution. These companies are using these technologies for regulatory compliance, surveillance, data quality assessment, and fraud detection.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or MBA in Finance
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) Core Concepts
(2) AI in Banking
(3) AI in Wealth and Asset Management
(4) AI in Insurance
(5) AI Strategy, Best Practices, Risks and Ethics

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Corporate Fund-Raising Initiatives in the Chinese Equity Markets
courses.description: This course delves into the major issues surrounding equity fund-raising in China. The principal focus is on initial public offerings (IPOs) and seasoned issues in Chinese stocks (including H- share, ‘red-chip’, private Chinese and ‘China-concept’ issuers) listed in Hong Kong. The characteristics of the various corporate entities and the nature of the funding methods utilized are critically explored. Case analysis of major IPO and seasoned equity issues (rights issues and private placings) features to amplify these objectives. Shanghai A- share listings are also considered as well as the various reforms to its constituent issuers. These include the transformation of non-tradable stock holdings into tradable form, the development of QFII and QDII schemes and the key reforms to China’s leading state-owned commercial banks. Finally, dual listings, such as American depositary receipts, and alternative routes to listing (‘reverse takeovers’) are also assessed. Upon completion of the course, students will have developed key insights into a major global funding activity.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes:
The course is structured to help students realize the following:
- An appreciation of the structure of initial public offerings as organized in Hong Kong and their significance in the global equity market context.
- An understanding of the ownership structure of Chinese state-owned enterprise (SOE) companies and the various types of Chinese stock issuer inhabiting the Chinese markets of Hong Kong, Shanghai and Shenzhen.
- A view into the various equity funding methods available to issuers generating funding in Hong Kong.
- Insights into the motivation for IPOs, seasoned issues, dual listings and ADRs.
- An overview of the major regulatory issues surrounding IPOs, seasoned issues, reverse takeovers and voluntary de-listings (privatizations) in Hong Kong.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Fundamentals of financial markets
2. Overview of China's capital markets
3. IPO
4. Chinese companies overseas listing
5. Beyond IPOs

courses.recommended_readings: Readings, include academic articles, equity research notes, research by consulting firms, business cases, and topical articles, will be used in and out of class. Detailed reading list for each topic will be provided in class.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Investments
courses.description: The objective of this course is to examine the problems and procedures of investment management, types of investment risks, and investment problems of the individual as well as the corporation. The performance and behaviour of the following financial assets are investigated: stocks, bonds, foreign exchange, financial futures, options, and warrants. The floating interest rate, the interest rate swap, and the currency swap are also examined.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA; or EMBA (Chinese)
courses.learning_outcomes: This course specifically focuses on the practical aspects of investing, and with emphasis on direct (unlisted) investments. Most of the examples are taken from the Asia Pacific region. While the course is taught from the perspective of management investment decision-making, it is intended also to sharpen the students' capabilities in deal structuring, financial valuation, qualitative evaluation, negotiating and deal completion. Principal objectives include: 1) offering the students through the reading materials an overview of investment; and 2) offering the students, through a series of short-form cases (“caselets”), the opportunity to strategize and be the decision maker in practical, “real world” business situations throughout the Asia Pacific region, which illustrate successful and unsuccessful investment strategies in Asia. The course materials will include evaluating investment opportunities in the “New Economy” such as internet solution providers.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: M&A: Incentives, Valuation & Impact
courses.description: This course is designed to integrate the materials of financial management and investments to analyse the merger and acquisitions (takeover) markets. The class will be conducted through both lectures and student presentations. Foundations in finance will be covered through lectures format. Note that the topics covered are an extension of (advanced) financial management, however the technical part will be reduced to a minimum. Students will be grouped and are required to present real cases in Hong Kong. It is not mandatory to work on a real project. However, students have the options to do so. The class is required to apply the efficient markets hypothesis to analyze stock markets' responses to takeover announcements. Welfare gains or losses to shareholders will also be computed. Computations for the cost of capital and intrinsic value of targets, by using the dividend discount model and the free cash model, will also be required. The final project should be a comprehensive integration of all materials learned in class.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA (Chinese)
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will able to identify the common motives behind mergers and acquisitions, evaluate the fair price to pay for the target, and understand the typical integration process. Students will also be able to understand the common risks behind acquisitions and steps to mitigate such risks.

courses.description: This course examines the valuation and market structure of derivative securities. Topics include the role of derivative securities, the determination of forward and futures prices, hedging strategies using futures, trading strategies with futures, properties of options, the pricing of stock options, options on indices, currencies and futures contracts, risk analysis, applications of option pricing models, biases in the Black-Scholes model, interest rate options, exotic options, risk management with options, and trading strategies with options. The course involves extensive and intensive use of computer and relevant software packages.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance; or MBA in Finance (40324)
courses.learning_outcomes: Students should have a good grasp of the economic concepts and quantitative skills for understanding and valuing derivative securities. Students should be able to interpret some economic phenomenon related to the derivatives. It is important for students to fully appreciate the economic underpinnings of various derivative pricing frameworks rather than the mechanical formulas. Students could apply the knowledge learnt from the course to potentially develop trading strategies in a rapidly changing market environment.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Credit derivatives
2. Interest rate derivatives
3. Equity derivatives
4. Commodity derivatives
5. Exotic options
6. Employee stock options
7. Real options
8. Volatility
9. Derivatives markets in Hong Kong
10. Derivatives markets in Mainland China
11. Impact of COVID-19 on derivatives markets

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Global Finance
courses.description: International dimensions of finance are examined in this course. The Fisher equation, Purchasing Power Parity, covered interest arbitrage, economic exposure analysis, use of derivative instruments and their valuation, management of global financial risk, and finance of international trade are some of the issues discussed. The course also covers Eurocurrency and capital markets, as well as institutional factors influencing capital acquisition and allocation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students can understand the theoretical backgrounds necessary to appreciate and understand problems faced by financial managers in an international setting.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Explain how and why exchange rates are determined
(2) Present a review of the economics of international trade and investment
(3) Investigate the functions and form of the global monetary systems and recent developments of international financial markets
(4) Examine the financial strategies of international firms
(5) Assess the special roles of international financial markets and financial engineering in enhancing firm values

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Fixed-income Securities Analysis
courses.description: The focus of this course is on the valuation of fixed-income securities and investment techniques in managing fixed income portfolios. Topics include the term structures of interest rates and forward rates; bond pricing, interest rate and reinvestment risks; risk and hedging in bond portfolio management; duration, convexity and portfolio immunization; corporate bonds, emerging-market bonds and default risks; fixed-income securities with embedded options; callable and convertible bonds, mortgage-backed securities; interest rate derivatives; and interest rate futures, swaps, caps and floors.

4. Interest Rate Risk and Immunization
5. Term Structure and Yield Curve / Yield Curve Strategy
6. Credit Risk and Rating
7. Bond Investment Strategies
8. Floaters and Inverse Floaters
9. Bond with Embedded Options
10. Guest speaker and course wrap-up

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Mergers & Acquisitions
courses.description: This course integrates areas within financial management and investments to analyse merger and acquisition (takeover) markets. The class will be conducted using both lectures and presentations. The topics covered in lectures include an overview of takeover markets, legal aspects and restrictions, capital budgeting techniques, the efficient market hypothesis, the market model and computation of abnormal returns, the dividend discount model and the free cash flow model. The topics covered in presentations will include US and Hong Kong cases of mergers, tender offers and leveraged buyouts. Amongst other things, the efficient market hypothesis is applied to analyse the stock market response to takeover announcement as well as a range of other issues including: welfare gains/losses associated with takeover, the cost of capital for due acquiror and the intrinsic value of the target (using dividend discount and free cashflow models).
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or MSc Finance; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Valuation review
2. Project NPV and stock price
3. Deal NPV: Cash versus Equity Considerations
4. Merger Arbitrage
5. M&A background 1: The M&A process
6. M&A background 2: Causes of M&As, M&A Waves and Sources of Synergy
7. M&A background 3: The Legal Context
8. M&A background 4: Hostile Takeovers, Takeover Defence and Takeover Tactics
9. Takeover Activism, Hedge Funds and Private Equity
10. M&A Conference Calls

courses.description: Python has rapidly become a powerful and versatile programming language widely used in the financial industry. This course is designed to provide students with the essential skills and knowledge to leverage Python for various financial applications. Throughout this course, students will gain hands-on experience with Python libraries and packages specifically tailored for financial analysis, modeling, and data manipulation. They will learn how to implement quantitative finance techniques, perform data analysis, build financial models, and automate repetitive tasks using Python. Key topics covered in this course include: 1) Overview of Python and its applications in the financial industry; 2) Managing Financial Data; 3) Implementing statistical analysis techniques for financial data; and 4) Financial Modeling and Simulation. This course will prepare students for advanced courses such as Algorithmic Trading Strategies and Machine Learning in Finance.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: International Finance
courses.description: Increasing globalization has expanded the scope and activities of firms beyond the domestic market. This course is designed to examine several important aspects of financial decisions and challenges multinational corporations (MNCs) face in light of rapid globalization. The topics covered in the course are organized into four sections. The first section introduces the foreign exchange market, which provides the foundation to understand global transactions. The second section discusses global capital markets and how MNCs obtain financing. The third section examines the various sources of foreign exchange risk and risk management strategies. And the final section presents techniques to evaluate cross-border investments and manage cash holdings.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:
•explain the key issues of financial management and challenges in a global setting,
•describe the characteristics of global capital markets and mechanisms for debt and equity capital raising especially cross-listings,
•describe the impact of exchange rate fluctuations and develop strategies for MNCs to effectively manage exchange rate risks, and evaluate foreign investment opportunities and analyze international capital budgeting issues.

International Debt and Equity Financing, CASE DUE: MAS
International Portfolio Investment
Foreign Currency Derivatives
Foreign Exchange Exposures
Risk Management and Foreign Currency Hedging
International Capital Budgeting, CASE DUE: GM
Multinational Cash Management, CASE DUE: GROUPE ARIEL

courses.title: Wealth Management
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with a management-level understanding of the history and development of the fast growing wealth management business in Hong Kong as well as Asia. Key topics to be discussed include the regulatory framework for wealth management industry, a review of the relationship between macro-economic cycle and wealth management product development and product shelf management strategies, roles and responsibilities of the various players within the wealth management industry value chain to fulﬁll various stages of individual customers’ ﬁnancial needs as well as the latest development of Hong Kong as one of the Family Ofﬁce Hub in Asia under Private Wealth business, business proposition including sales and marketing strategies, and the technology and operational infrastructure required to support the business process and to deliver exceptional customer experience. Moreover, this course will provide students with the opportunity to examine and to develop their understanding of the cause, development, and impact of some of the most signiﬁcant ﬁnancial crises during the last three decades and to develop an appreciation and understanding of the impact to customers and the wealth management business. Topics to be discussed include the Wall Street Crash in 1929 followed by the Great Depression, the Black Monday in 1987, Asian Financial Crisis in 1997, Dot-Com Bubble in 2000, Subprime Mortgage Crisis in 2007, and Covid in 2019. We will ﬁrst examine the inter-relationship between the development of political economy, technology and ﬁnancial market; then, on the impact in the ﬁnancial regulatory framework, in the wealth management industry, and to the individual investors.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to explain the key components and success factors of managing a wealth management business through the market life cycles, and for those students who are interested in developing further academic study and research, or in preparing them to take up senior leadership roles within their company or in the wealth management industry.
This course is suitable for those students who are individual investors or are involved in financial / investment decision for your company, or those who have solid experience and track record and in managerial positions within any functional departments in the wealth management industry, or those who are interested in developing further academic study and research in the wealth management industry.
courses.course_syllabus:
1, Wealth management service providers & customer

2, Personal financial needs, macroeconomics cycle, product development and management

3, Customer Experience

4, Regulatory Framework

5, Financial Crisis & Wealth Management Business

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Financial Policy
courses.description: The objective of this course is to integrate various subfields of finance for the formulation of financial policies. The focus is on the application of financial theory to real-world business decisions, financing and restructuring strategies. The course also emphasizes the impact of institutional constraints on managers' financial decision-making and the implementation of financial strategies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:
- describe and characterize various advanced theories on firms’ financing policies
- evaluate tradeoffs in the choice of an optimal capital structure
- understand the interactions between investment, payout and financing policies
- perform data analysis regarding firms’ capital structure and interpret observed data patterns
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Review of fundamental theories and bond pricing
2. Review of stock pricing, asset pricing theories, and options
3. Corporate ownership, governance, and debt financing
4. Cost of capital, payout policies, and review for mid-term
5. Trade-off debt theory, and debt financing
6. Different types of debt financing and agency conflicts
7. Pecking order theory and leverage puzzles
8. Venture capital and IPO
9. Risk-shifting evidence and review for the final exam
10. Case presentations
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: Principles of Corporate Finance, 12th edition, Richard Brealey, Stewart Myers, Franklin Allen, McGraw-Hill/Irwin.
courses.recommended_readings: Options, Futures and Other Derivatives, 8th edition, by John Hull, Pearson Education.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Current Fintech Trends
courses.description:
The world of global financial services is changing rapidly with the emergence of financial technologies, commonly referred as fintech. This course will cover key fintech concepts such as virtual banking, blockchain, digital currencies, tokenization, and others.

Examining a variety of case studies drawn from the industry, students will learn about recent developments in fintech from the perspectives of entrepreneurs, consumers and regulators. While Asian cases will be emphasized, some American and European examples will also be discussed so that students will acquire a global view of the subject. A few industry practitioners will be invited as guest speakers to share their entrepreneurial experience in fintech with students.

This is an introductory course where computer programming is not required. However, basic knowledge in financial valuation analysis and statistics will be useful. The objective is to learn about the use of new technologies in solving business problems, and appreciate how current fintech trends will impact and shape the financial industry in the future.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme;Pre-requistie: FINA5010
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, students are expected to:
1. Have a holistic view of the fintech ecosystem and current trends, and understand their implications on the future of finance.
2. Have a good grasp of basic concepts of new technologies and their applications in the financial industry.
3. Acquire basic industry, financial, and entrepreneurial knowledge to evaluate the business viability of some fintech companies; and to potentially develop a business plan for a new fintech idea.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to fintech ecosystem
2. Virtual banking
3. Insurtech
4. Open banking
5. Blockchain and its business applications
6. Digital currencies
7. Initial coin offering
8. Tokenization
9. Security token offering
10. Startup financing
11. Crowdfunding
12. Regulation of fintech
13. Cryptoasset valuation model

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Machine Learning in Finance
courses.description:
This course provides an overview of the basic tools in machine learning, with emphases on applications in finance. Machine learning plays an important role in FinTech. Individual investors and financial institutions who are able to leverage these new tools and technology will have a significant advantage. This course discusses these new opportunities and challenges. It seeks to equip students with these highly coveted skills in the market. We will cover topics including: cluster analysis, decision trees, support vector machines, flexible discriminants, and neural networks, accompanied with the corresponding financial applications.

Real world finance problems often deal with large datasets, traditionally with historical price and return as well as data on financial statements. More recently, other databases like consumer credit and online data (e.g., Google search, news media, satellite images, etc.) are also becoming more important for financial analysts. Dealing with such large datasets require tools to manipulate them, and we will introduce the use of Python and detailed instructions on how to perform analysis on large datasets. Once students become comfortable with the use of Python and manipulation of large sets, we will introduce students to tools in machine learning, which play an important role in our financial market, from approving loans, managing portfolios, to assessing risks. Advances in machine learning technology have enabled financial institutions to explore the applications of artificial intelligence in areas like customer service, personal finance, wealth management, and risk management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, we expect students to be a competent programmer in Python as well as having solid knowledge of various methodologies used in machine learning. Students are expected to apply the acquainted machine learning techniques to solve different tasks in a wide range of financial topics. The course requires the use of Python. We will provide one review class for programing and mathematics at the beginning of the semester to get students better prepared. Prior knowledge of Python is not a requirement for this course but students who are uncomfortable with coding should not take this course. The course also makes heavy use of statistics, and students who have difficulties with quantitative materials are not suggested to take this course.

科目結束時，我們希望學生能熟練掌握Python編程，並且對機器學習各種方法的原理和實際操作有深入理解。同時我們也希望學生能熟悉運用機器學習各種方法來解決不同場景下的金融問題並提出有效的解決方案。本科目需要大量使用編程語言Python。在學期開始時，我們將提供一節編程和統計基礎複習課，以便學生為之後的科目學習做好準備。本科目不要求課前具備Python編程背景，但需要學生具備基本的編程語言知識以及一定的編程經歷。同時本科目將大量使用統計學知識，學生選課前需要對數理統計和定量分析有一定瞭解。
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction to Machine Learning and Applications in Finance
- Cluster Analysis and Unsupervised Learning
- Linear Methods for Regression and Classification
- Decision Trees, Support Vector Machines, and Flexible Discriminants
- Neural Networks, Deep Learning, and Other AI Applications

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Venture Capital & Private Equity
courses.description: The course will outline the mechanisms of venture capital (VC) investment and the financing of startups and early growth firms. As VC is a subset of private equity, the course will discuss the management, legal and marketing issues of private equity in general. Topics include raising and structuring private equity funds, the limited partnership, and fund strategies. The course will consider the investment decision of institutional investors in private equity and how funds are structured to meet their needs. It will discuss post-subscription private equity fund management - deal screening, evaluation, negotiation, disbursement, investee management, valuation and exit - and will consider specifically the perspective of the VC investee company - alternative sources of financing, how to approach a VC to maximize chances of success, and governance issues in VC financed firms. The course may also delve into public versus private equity buyouts, valuation of buyouts and corporate restructuring under private equity.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes: Students should be able to have a general understanding of private equity investment cycle from pre-investment, investment, post-investment and exit. In addition, the typical private equity fund legal structure are covered and explained such that students shall be able to understand the basic idea of designing a private equity fund which caters for the requirements of investor and the investment manager. Students shall also be able to learn valuation, negotiation and several key considerations on how does a PE/VC investment decision is made, both from the investor and the investee perspectives. As such, students shall be able to have the basic understanding of PE/VC industry and be able to communicate with stakeholders typically involve in PE/VC deals.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction of course structure
2. The PE&VC industry & fund structure
3. Project evalutation and valuation
4. Common financial instruments for VC/PE investment
5. Due diligence
6. Investment structure (WFOE) and exit strategy
7. Case study and hot investment topics
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: Deal Terms – The Finer Points of Venture Capital (Deal Structure, Valuation, Terms Sheet, Stock Options and Getting VC Deals Done) by Alex Wilmerding

courses.description: This course covers advanced topics in financial economics such as: individual investment decisions under uncertainty with complete markets and under constraints. Viability and state-price densities, equivalent martingale measures, general equilibrium and rational expectations, foundations of the theory of information.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Finance
courses.learning_outcomes: This is a quantitative and seminar course in asset pricing. Students will gain key insights in both classic asset pricing theories and recent work in the area. Students will also be familiarized with the tools and methodologies that are commonly used in the literature to empirically test asset pricing theories.

courses.title: Seminar in Corporate Finance

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Fundamentals of Derivatives Trading Strategies
courses.description: This course intends to offer students insight into the implementation of options theory in the practical trading environment. The main strategies for trading derivatives will be discussed and the students are to apply their knowledge in practical trading sessions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance, MSc Financial Technology or PgD FinTech
courses.learning_outcomes:
The primary objective of this course is to provide an introduction to the research and development of derivatives trading. At the end of the semester, students are expected to be able to:
~ have a basic understanding of research and development in trading mechanisms of derivatives market
~ construct and manage a real-life portfolio by using data retrieved from Bloomberg and Reuters
~ have an in-depth understanding of the strategies involved in arbitrage and hedging
~ evaluate the performance of their portfolio against that of a benchmark chosen
courses.course_syllabus:
~ Introduction to Trading: Markets in Practice
~ Introduction to Futures: Specifications and Strategies
~ Introdcution to Option Theory: Recap Hull
~ Practical Aspects of Option Theory: Delta-Hedging, Gamma and other Greeks
~ Practical Aspects of Option Theory: Implied Volatility
~ Managing Options Portfolio's and Scenario Analysis
~ Market Making: Trading Implied Volatility
~ Market Making: Position Adjustment and Quoting
~ Live Trading: Managing an Options Market Making Book
~ Advanced Options Trading: Early Exercise, Dispersion Strategies
~ Volatility Arbitrage
~ Live Trading: Managing a Volatility Arbitrage Book
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Focus group discussions with at least two small groups of students
CTE questionnaires
Reflection of instructors
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by the course teacher
courses.recommended_readings:

courses.description: It provides rigorous treatment of current empirical research in asset pricing. It covers issues in testing different asset pricing models, dealing with predictability in asset returns, anomalies and behavioral finance, numerical analysis of derivative securities.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Finance
courses.learning_outcomes: The goal of this course is to provide an understanding of the key empirical research design and methods used in asset pricing. After completing this course, students should be able to understand the empirical methodologies that are commonly used in asset pricing, as well as the pros and cons associated with each of the methodologies. Students may also be asked to replicate the empirical results in a published paper.

courses.description: The course covers both micro- and macro-economics fundamental to finance practice. Topics for microeconomics include: game theory and its application in finance, asymmetric information, consumer and producer behaviors, externality, public goods, information technology and network effect, asset markets and investment under uncertainty, mean variance optimization and portfolio theory, and behavioral economics. Topics for macroeconomics include: classical macroeconomics, Keynesian macroeconomics, output, inflation and unemployment, trade and exchange rate, economic policies, and economic growth.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the course, students should:
- have an applied understanding of micro- and macroeconomics and be able to critically evaluate relevant theories and frameworks
- be able to interpret economic data and policies for financial decisions
- be able to integrate economics with other disciplinary knowledge (e.g., accounting, law, and capital markets) in developing financing strategies for their own firms and solving financial management problems
- be able to communicate practical issues in economics in a professional manner with co-workers and/or relevant experts
courses.course_syllabus:
Microeconomics
1. Game theory introduction: normal form, dominant strategy, Nash equilibrium, extended form, sub-game perfect equilibrium, credible threat, credible commitment, prisoner’s dilemma, simple applications

2. Game theory applied to finance
- Hostile takeover
- Bubbles

3. Asymmetric information
- Adverse selection
- Signaling
- Moral hazard
- Incentives contracting

4. Consumer and producer behaviors: utility function, gains from voluntary transactions, production function, behavior of monopoly

5. Externality, public goods, information technology and network effect

6. Asset markets and investment under uncertainty
(Mean variance optimization and portfolio theory)

7. Behavioral economics

Macroeconomics
1. Classical macroeconomics
- GDP, inflation, and unemployment - frequent misconception about these terms
- Equilibrium output and employment
- Quantity theory of money
- Classical theory of the interest rate
- Policy implication of the classical equilibrium model

2. Keynesian macroeconomics
- IS-LM model
- Policy effects analysis using IS-LM model
- Aggregate supply and demand
- Keynes vs the classics

3. Output, inflation and unemployment
- Monetarists’ viewpoints
- Keynesian output-inflation trade-off
- Natural rate of employment - Friedman
- New classical
- Keynesian counter-critique of New Classical
- Real business cycle
- New Keynesian

4. Trade and exchange rate
- Comparative advantage
- Exchange rate
- Capital account and current account
- Mundell-Fleming model

5. Economic policies
- Monetary policy (central banking tools, inflation targeting, quantitative easing)
- Fiscal policy (automatic stabilizers, fiscal deficit)

6. Economic growth
- Solow growth model
- Endogenous growth theory
- Supply side economics
- Keynesian critique of supply side economics

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Foreign Exchange in Theory and Practice
courses.description: This course will cover exchange rate theory, exchange rate policy, and statistical work on exchange rate determination. It will also touch on important topics of the day, such as China’s exchange rate regime, global imbalances, and the problems of the Eurozone.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes: After this course, students should be well grounded in the theory and market dynamics underlying the foreign exchange market, global trade and capital flows, currency regimes, and gain an in-depth analysis of the current financial issues confronting policy and decision makers.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction. Nominal and real exchange rates. Overview of the global foreign exchange market and the international financial system. Accounting for the flows of goods and capital. Covered and uncovered interest rate parity.

2. Basic models of exchange rate determination. Absolute and relative purchasing power parity. The monetarist model.

3. Exchange rates in the Keynesian model. The Mundell-Fleming model, and the effect of monetary and fiscal policy.

4. Rational expectations and the Dornbusch overshooting model.

5. Do exchange rate models work (I)? Academic research on basic exchange rate models, and the state of play.

6. Do exchange rate models work (II)? Recent work on exchange rate. Nonlinear models and empirical work on technical analysis.

7. Fixed exchange rates, managed exchange rate regimes and crawling pegs. Speculative attacks on fixed exchange rates.

8. The choice of an exchange rate regime. Exchange rate regimes in emerging Asia. The evolution of Japan’s exchange rate regime.

9. The euro. History of the European monetary system, the creation and adoption of the euro, and how the single currency contributes to the current problems in the Eurozone.

10. Fundamental equilibrium models of exchange rates (FEERs).

11. Capital account liberalization. Exchange rate determination with a closed capital account. Capital controls in emerging Asia, and the current debate about capital account liberalization.

12. China’s currency regime. Is the renminbi undervalued? China’s currency policy good for China? Is it bad for the US? What are the benefits and costs of accumulating foreign exchange reserves? Should China liberalize the capital account?

13. International reserve currencies. The role of sovereign wealth funds and central banks in global financial markets.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Behavioral Finance
courses.description:
Traditional finance seeks to understand financial markets assuming that investors are "rational". Rationality means that investors can access to and have the ability to process information correctly and that competition between investors ensures that securities are correctly priced to reflect all available information. That is, the market is efficient. However, recent studies suggest that markets are not efficient and that investors are not fully rational. For example, particular trading strategies based on past information such as past returns and accounting information are able to outperform the markets. In addition, studies find that investors are committed to certain heuristic-based biases and frame dependent such as overconfidence, optimism, self-attribution, illusion of control, loss aversion, representativeness heuristic, anchoring, availability, ambiguity aversion, hindsight, flaming, etc. Behavioral biases combined with limits to arbitrage may result in securities not to be correctly priced.

This course will help students understand how individuals’ attitudes and behaviors affect their financial decisions and financial markets. In the practical side, this course will emphasize the role of investors’ psychological biases on various types of market inefficiency and show that how sophisticated investors can take advantage of these behavioral biases. This is a research oriented course with emphasis on both psychology theories and data analysis skills.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance
courses.course_syllabus:
I. Introduction
Foundation I: Expected Utility Theory and its Violations
(Group Formation)

II. Foundation II: Investor Psychology and Behavioral Biases
- Heuristics Biases
- Frame Dependence
- Overconfidence and Attribution Biases
- Inattention
- Mood

III. Foundation III: Market Efficiency and Challenge to Market Efficiency
- Efficient Market Hypothesis Revisited
- Asset Pricing Anomalies Driven by Psychological Biases
- Limits to Arbitrage
- Disagreement
Case Study: Behavioral Finance at JP Morgan (HBS Case: 9-207-084)

IV. Financial Market Bubble and Crisis
Case Study: Financial Crisis in Asia: 1997-1998 (HBS Case: 9-709-004)

V. Data Mining Workshop I: Programming with Trading Strategies

VI. Behavioral Corporate Finance I: Mergers and Acquisitions

VII. Data Mining Workshop II: Event Studies of Corporate Events & Search Techniques of Corporate Information

VIII. Behavioral Corporate Finance II: IPOs and SEOs

IX. Behavioral Corporate Finance III: Financial Analysts

X. Presentation of Group Projects

XI. Final Project Submission

courses.title: Commercial Banking
courses.description: This course is designed to examine and analyse bank's major functions and the principles underlying modern banking operations and practices. It covers issues including bank's payment operations and their roles, the general principles of bank lending, the range of credit services available and the principles of taking securities, trade finance, credit cards and some other major banking services. Various bank risk management methods are conducted in a simulated environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA in Finance; or MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completing this course, students are expected to understand the business models of commercial banking, along with key management techniques and tools.
courses.course_syllabus: We will compare the organizational and operational structures of banks, with services related to both corporate and retail banking. As a global regulatory trend, capital management is becoming a key requirement and we’ll discuss and quantify the rationale behind it. Management practice and evolution in western banks will be introduced, and we will further extend the discussion to the practices in Chinese banks.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Insurance and Risk Management
courses.description: This course deals with risk management functions in business; the identification and measurement of business loss exposures; major tools of risk management; analysis of insurance contracts and their uses; methods and problems of insurance pricing; operations of insurers and major insurances policies; family property and liability risk management; and government regulation of insurance.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will:
- be able to understand the theories, principles and practices of risk management and insurance.
- understand how corporate risk managers are dealing with risks and arranging insurance policies.
- be familiar with risk management and insurance innovations and some current insurance issues around the world.
courses.course_syllabus: This course offers an introduction to the theories, principles and practices of risk management and insurance. The emphasis will be placed on the corporate property and liability risk and insurance.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Merger, Acquisition and Reconstruction of Corporate Finance
courses.description: This course integrates areas within financial management and investments to analyse merger and acquisition (takeover) markets. The class will be conducted using both lectures and presentations. The topics covered in lectures will include the overview of takeover markets, legal aspects and restrictions, capital budgeting techniques, the efficient market hypothesis, the market model and computation of abnormal returns, the dividend discount model and the free cash flow model. The topics covered in presentation will include US and Hong Kong cases of mergers, tender offers and leverage buyouts. The class is required to apply the efficient market hypothesis to analyse the stock market responses to takeover announcements. In addition, consideration will be given to welfare gains/losses associated with takeover, the cost of capital for due acquirer and the intrinsic value of the target (using dividend discount and free cashflow models).
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will:
- understand how to analyse strategic activities of a company and target a company
- be familiar with different ways of merger and acquisition
- understand how a targeted company adopt anti-M&A strategies to protect the interests of the company and shareholders
- be able to design and carry out M&A activities, including due diligence, valuation, post merger integration, etc.
- be familiar with the development history and trend in M&A, various M&A activities, motives and relevant theories
courses.course_syllabus: We will analyze the company's strategic activities, and determine the target company's M&A method.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Entrepreneurship in Finance
courses.description: Entrepreneurship in Finance is a capstone course that gives all students the opportunity to integrate all they have learned before to develop an actual business model. The course will introduce entrepreneurial process, and develop skills critical for starting and succeeding in a new venture. It emphasizes the framework and skills needed to identify business ideas, recognize entrepreneurial opportunities, raising and structuring financing and making strategic decisions. Students are required to write and present a comprehensive business plan.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Law and the Securities Markets
courses.description: This course is designed to introduce students already familiar with the economics of securities markets to the law that governs those markets and the transactions in securities they are designed to execute. The course will closely examine actual legal documentation to show its basic structure and purpose. Further, the course will analyze basic legal principles that shape the law and regulation of corporate finance and securities markets, such as legal strategies to overcome asymmetric information, moral hazard and agency problems, as well as techniques to secure prior claims against assets held in the possession of another entity in any bankruptcy proceedings regarding that entity.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the course, students shall:
- be able to read legal documents relevant for financial decision making
- have a thorough understanding of the underlying legal principles related to regulation and outside regulation and critically evaluate relevant theories and frameworks
- be able to appreciate the importance of legal dimensions in corporate finance
- be able to integrate the legal principles with other disciplinary knowledge (e.g., economics and accounting) in developing financing strategies for their own firms and solving financial management problems
- be able to communicate issues involving law and securities market in a professional manner with co-workers and/or relevant experts
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Legal issues other than regulation
1. 1. Creating securities
1. 1.1. Contract law issues: the terms of the notes and the role of standard agreements
1. 1.2. Property law issues: payment for shares
1. 1.3. Company law issues: issuing shares of stock
1. 1.4. The legal nature of derivatives and the standardization of their terms

2. Selling securities
2. 1. The underwriting agreement: contracting to distribute risk
2. 2. Taking collateral
2. 3. Risk management transactions, in particular repo transactions

3. Legal issues of regulation
3. 1. Regulation of the Primary Market
3. 1.1. Public offers, documentation and approvals
3. 1.2. Private offers, prerequisites to quality as a private offer
3. 1.3. Liability for false or misleading disclosures
3. 2. The activities and supervision of market participants
3. 2.1. Exchanges
3. 2.2. Trading platforms
3. 2.3. Brokers
3. 3. Laws against market abuse
3. 3.1. Insider trading
3. 3.2. Market manipulation

- Securities law / Alastair Hudson. London : Sweet & Maxwell, 2008.
- Financial markets in Hong Kong : law and practice / Berry Fong-Chung Hsu, Laurence Lu-Jen Li, Paul Lejot. Oxford ; New York : Oxford University Press, 2006.

courses.title: Securitization and Structured Finance
courses.description: This course introduces students to fundamental concepts of securitization and the wide array of structured products in the financial market, especially in the context of China. Topics include exotic derivatives and credit derivative, followed by detailed discussions on popular structured products in different asset classes, structuring rationales of the products, and the typical transaction cycle in banks.

1. Corporate Credit Rating
Issuer default rating, recovery rating, S-REIT credit analysis, profit manipulation, early warning signals
2. Securitization Rating
Securitization process and participants, legal structure, financial structure, credit enhancement, residential mortgage backed securities
3. CDS, CLN, CDO
4. Recent development of structured finance in China

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Introduction to Behavioral Finance
courses.description: In this course we will use psychology and more realistic settings to guide and develop alternative theories of financial markets. We will examine how the insights of behavioral finance complement the traditional paradigm and shed light on investors' trading patterns, the behavior of asset prices, corporate finance, and various Wall Street institutions and practices.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will:
- understand why and how value investment can be an effective investment approach by using the academic paradigm of behavioral finance
- be familiar with private equity, asset prices and corporate finance in the context of urban economics
- understand how these markets have been developing in Mainland China compared with the international experiences
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Non-behavioral finance: Introduction; Why we care: The roles of securities prices in the economy; Efficient markets hypothesis (EMH): Definitions; Theoretical arguments for EMH; Equilibrium risk models; Pro-EMH evidence;
2. Some motivating evidence: Bubbles; Return predictability in the stock market; Data mining; Joint hypothesis problem; Low risk firms earn higher average returns (failure of CAPM)
3. Demand by average investors: Nontraditional preferences – prospect theory and loss aversion; Evolutionary perspective on human
4. Demand by arbitrageurs: Definition of arbitrageur; Long-short trades; Risk vs. Horizon; Transaction costs and short-selling costs; Fundamental risk; Noise-trader risk; Professional arbitrage; Destabilizing informed trading (positive feedback, predation)
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
