courses.description: The course introduces probability, stochastic processes, and statistics required for quantitative finance study. Topics include: time value of money, probability, probability distributions and descriptive statistics, sampling and estimation, hypothesis testing, correlation analysis and regression, time series analysis, simulation analysis and technical analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the course, students should:
- have the basic skills and techniques in mathematics, probability, and statistics required for understanding theories of quantitative risk management, mathematical financial modeling, computational finance, and financial econometrics developed in other courses of the programme.
- have an appreciation of quantitative methods and their importance in analyzing, structuring, trading, and investing as quantitative analysts.
- be able to conduct various mathematical analyses, results of which are used to make informed financial decisions.
courses.course_syllabus:
A. Time Value of Money
B. Probability
C. Probability Distributions and Descriptive Statistics
D. Sampling and Estimation
E. Hypothesis Testing
F. Correlation Analysis and Regression
G. Time Series Analysis
H. Simulation Analysis
I. Technical Analysis
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: This course will be taught primarily from the lecture notes. There is no required textbook.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Finance Field Study
courses.description: This course consists of assignments, case reports and/or presentations along with a week-long residential programme in various countries arranged by the MSc Programme in Finance. The goal in taking classroom sessions abroad is to expose our students to a wide spectrum of finance related issues, such as capital markets, derivative markets, venture capital, economics, politics, social issues, business functions and financial systems of the host country. Site visits to multi-national financial institutions, joint ventures and regulatory bodies might be included.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students will gain a basic understanding of the current finance practices and related issues in the corresponding country.
courses.course_syllabus: This course consists of a week-long residential programme in selected countries along with assignments. The goal in taking classroom sessions abroad is to expose our students to a wide spectrum of finance related issues, such as capital markets, financial innovation, economic and social environment, business activities and financial systems of the host country. Site visits focus on financial institutions and startup companies complemented by cultural experiences.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Quantitative Risk Management
courses.description: This course explores quantitative methods in credit risk management and examines market risks, operational risks, integrated risk management, and risk management information technology. Basic Value-at-Risk (VaR) methodologies such as historical simulation, parametric VaR, delta-gamma approximation and Monte-Carlo simulation will be covered. Defaults of bank loans, corporate bonds, and/or counter-parties are addressed. Reduced-form models and structure models are discussed, with application of CreditmetricsTM and KMV methodologies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the course, students should:
- have a thorough understanding of quantitative risk management and appreciate its importance in analyzing, structuring, trading, and investing as quantitative analysts
- be able to critically evaluate theories, frameworks, and techniques of quantitative risk management
- be able to reason quantitatively using different methodologies
- have the operational skills for assessing and managing credit risks using IT systems
- be able to integrate the quantitative risk management principles with other disciplinary knowledge (e.g., economics, accounting, and law) in developing financing strategies for their own firms and solving financial management problems
- be able to communicate risk management issues in a professional manner with co-workers and/or relevant experts
courses.course_syllabus:
Risk & Risk Management
- Introduction
- Market risk & operational risk
- Integrated risk management
- Risk management information technology

Basic methodologies
- Value-at-Risk (VaR)
- Historical simulation
- Parametric VaR
- Delta-gamma approximation
- Monte-Carlo simulation

Portfolio risk management
- Portfolio risk management
- Asset allocation
- Measuring the performance of portfolio managers
- Defaults of bank loans, corporate bonds and/or counter-parties
- Reduced-form models and structure models to credit risk CreditmetricsTM and KMV methodologies

Operational risk management
- Techniques to operational risk management
courses.feedback_evaluation: A course-end evaluation and reflection of teachers, including evidence from assessment, will be conducted.
courses.required_readings: There is not a single textbook that covers all the topics and the course would be based on a set of lecture notes.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Bank and Insurance Capital
courses.description: The course offers a comprehensive understanding of Basel I, II, and III. The standard internal ratings-based (IRB) approach, as well as the foundation internal ratings-based (FIRB), and advanced internal ratings-based (AIRB) approaches, will be covered. The 3 Pillars for banking capital will be explored. Students are guided through practical implementation of different capital requirements under different regulatory frameworks.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Finance
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the course, students should:
- have a thorough understanding of all Basel frameworks and appreciate their importance in analyzing, structuring, trading, and investing as quantitative analysts
- be able to critically evaluate all Basel requirements on capital
- have the operational skills for managing capitals according to IRB, FIRB, and AIRB approaches
- be able to integrate the Basel principles with other disciplinary knowledge (e.g., economics, accounting, and law) in developing financing strategies for their own firms and solving financial management problems
- be able to communicate issues on bank and insurance company capital requirements in a professional manner with co-workers and/or relevant experts
courses.course_syllabus:
International Capital Frameworks
- International convergence of capital measurement and capital standards - for financial & monetary stability
- Scope of application of Basel
- Basel I, II, and III

Credit Risk
- Standard internal ratings-based (IRB) approach
- Foundation internal ratings-based (FIRB) approach
- Advanced internal ratings-based (AIRB) approach

Three Basel pillars
- The First Pillar - Minimum Capital Requirements
- The Second Pillar - Supervisory Review Process
- The Third Pillar - Market Discipline

Practical implementation
- Case studies
courses.feedback_evaluation: A course-end evaluation and reflection of teachers, including evidence from assessment, will be conducted.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Mathematical Financial Modeling and Structured Solutions
courses.description: The course introduces mathematical modeling concepts and techniques for financial applications. The classic Black-Scholes Model, local volatility, stochastic volatility are critically evaluated. Interest rate models such as Ho-Lee, Hull-White, Heath-Jarrow-Morton (HJM), Libor Market Model are discussed. Cross currency models for foreign exchanges and modeling for commodity are also covered.

courses.learning_outcomes:
After the course, students should:
- have an applied understanding of mathematical finance modeling and appreciate their importance in analyzing, structuring, trading, and investing as quantitative analysts
- have the mathematical / technical skills for developing mathematical finance models under guidance
- be able to adopt the modeling techniques in developing financing strategies for their own firms and solving financial management problems

Mathematical financial modeling
- Problems of classic Black-Scholes Model
- Local volatility
- Stochastic volatility

Interest rate models
- Ho-Lee
- Hull-White
- Heath-Jarrow-Morton (HJM)
- Libor Market Model

Other models
- Cross currency models for foreign exchanges
- Modeling for commodity

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Financial Econometrics
courses.description: This course covers econometrics used in empirical finance. Topics will include univariate and multivariate linear models, parametric and nonparametric models of volatility, evaluation of capital asset pricing model, arbitrage pricing theory, risk management models. The course makes extensive use of computer-based applications to draw inferences.

- have the required technical and / or mathematical understanding for mastering econometric theories and frameworks
- be able to use computer-based software for analyzing financial data to draw inferences
courses.course_syllabus:
- Features for Financial Data
- Linear Time Series Models
- Parametric Volatility Models, GARCH and Stochastic Volatility
- Nonparametric Volatility Measures
- Nonlinear Models
- Risk and Return

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Economics for Actuaries
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the basic tools of micro- and macroeconomic analysis, and how these can be used in an insurance business environment to help decision making and behavior. Topics include macroeconomic role of insurance, the demand and supply of insurance, adverse selection, moral hazard, imperfections in insurance markets, utility functions, and the life cycle hypothesis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, students are expected to critically appraise key economic concepts, models and theories of microeconomics and macroeconomics; to apply a range of techniques including calculations and manipulation of diagrammatic representations to solve problems related to economic concepts and models; to evaluate the role of the government and the central bank and the instruments available to them to manage the economy, and to recognize and relate the relevance of economic theory to the wider business environment and describe the link between these theories to the practical application of individual businesses.
courses.course_syllabus: Micro: Supply and demand; utility theory and risk aversion; production choices; competition; Macro: Fiscal and monetary policy; exchange rates; factors affecting inflation, unemployment, exchange rates and economic growth; introductory game theory; introduction to insurance economics.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Course Teaching Evaluation. To be conducted during the last two weeks of lectures.
• E-mail communications with the instructor.
• Performance in test/examination/essay/presentation. Assessment of what has been achieved by the students.
courses.required_readings: Economics by Sloman, Garratt & Guest, 10th Edition, Pearson
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Accounting and Corporate Finance
courses.description: The course provides both a framework for and the tools necessary to analyse financial statements of an insurance company. Topics include financial ratios, equity and debt capital, weighted-average cost of capital, capital budgeting, and rates of investment return.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.course_syllabus:
Concepts and topics listed below should be covered:

Accounting
• Describe the basic principles of corporate taxation and the taxation of investments held by institutions.
• Explain why companies are required to produce annual reports.
• Explain fundamental accounting concepts and terms, and describe the main sources of accounting regulation.
• Explain the structure and purpose of the income statement, balance sheet, and statement of cash flows, and the interactions between them.
• Construct simple statements of financial position and profit or loss.
• Calculate and interpret financial ratios.

Corporate Finance
•Explain the characteristics of various forms of equity capital from the point of view of the issuer and the investor.
• Explain the characteristics of various forms of long-term debt capital from the point of view of the issuer and the investor.
• Explain the characteristics of various forms of short- and medium-term financing from the point of view of the issuer and the investor.
• Calculate weighted-average cost of capital.
• Explain the main methods of capital budgeting.
• Calculate a project’s investment return.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Course Teaching Evaluation. To be conducted during the last two weeks of lectures.
• E-mail communications with the instructor.
• Performance in test/examination/essay/presentation. Assessment of what has been achieved by the students.
courses.required_readings:
Watson, D. and Head, A (2010). Corporate Finance: Principles and Practice. FT Prentice Hall.
Atrill, P. and McLaney, E. (2013). Accounting and Finance for Non-specialists. FT Prentice Hall.
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Probability with Applications in Finance and Insurance
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to develop knowledge of the fundamental mathematical tools for quantitatively assessing risk. The application of these tools to problems encountered in actuarial analysis is emphasized. Topics include derivatives and integrals of multivariate functions, simple differential equations, general probability, Bayes’ Theorem, univariate and multivariate probability distributions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes:
The purposes of this course are
(1) to introduce tools in probability theory for quantitatively assessing risk, and
(2) to build a solid background in mathematics for uses in later courses.

After following the course, students are expected to be
• familiar with the basic mathematical tools that are useful in actuarial science
• able to use probability to analyze risk
• able to handle calculations involving univariate and multivariate probability distributions
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) General probability:
Set notation, independent and mutually exclusive events, addition and multiplication law, combinatorics, conditional probability and Bayes’ theorem

(2) Univariate probability distributions:
The binomial, negative binomial, geometric, hypergeometric, Poisson, uniform, exponential, chi-square, beta, Pareto, lognormal, gamma, Weibull, and normal distribution. Probability mass function / density function, distribution function, quantiles and percentiles, mean and variance, mode and median, moment generating function, transformation

(3) Multivariate probability distributions:
Joint pmf/pdf, joint distribution, the bivariate normal distribution, joint MGF, conditional and marginal distribution, covariance and correlation, order statistics, the central limit theorem
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Course Teaching Evaluation. To be conducted during the last two weeks of lectures.
• E-mail communications with the instructor.
• Performance in test/examination/essay/presentation. Assessment of what has been achieved by the students.
courses.required_readings: Sheldon M. Ross (2009). A First Course in Probability. 8th Ed., Prentice Hall.
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Financial Mathematics for Actuaries
courses.description: This course discusses the mathematical and technical aspects of the theory of interest in both discrete and continuous time. Topics include: measurement of interest and discount rates, accumulated value and present value, annuities, sinking funds, amortization of debt, determination of yield rates on securities and bond evaluations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes: On completion of this course, students should be able to understand the time value of money and to calculate interest rates and discount factors. They should be able to apply these concepts to the pricing and managing of simple, fixed-income financial instruments and the assessment of investment projects.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics to be discussed include:
• Interest Accumulation and Time Value of Money
• Annuities
• Interest Rates and Rates of Return
• Loans and Costs of Borrowing
• Bonds and Bond Management
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Course Teaching Evaluation. To be conducted during the last two weeks of lectures.
• E-mail communications with the instructor.
• Performance in test/examination/essay/presentation. Assessment of what has been achieved by the students.

courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Statistics for Risk Modelling
courses.description: The course is an introduction to mathematical statistics and basic risk modelling. Its goal is to help students understand the theoretical foundations of modern insurance analytics and risk management. The course covers the fundamental statistical concepts of inference, parameter estimation, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing using the tools of probability theory.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, students would acquire a knowledge in estimation and inference useful for actuarial work and predictive modeling.
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) Obtain parameter estimates of parametric distribution, and evaluate the properties of the estimates and compare different methods using the following notions: unbiasedness, efficiency, minimum variance, consistency, mean-square error.

(2) Construct confidence intervals for parameters in simple set up related to mean and variance of normal distributions, and proportions of a population using CLT.

(3) Understand the concept of statistical inference and compute the following for simple tests: level of significance (alpha), beta, power, p-value, critical region.

(4) Construct critical regions of tests of hypothesis using Neyman-Pearson lemma and likelihood ratio tests (with the help of Wilk’s theorem). Derive classical tests for normal populations, proportions, and the chi-square goodness-of-fit test.

(5) Understand the concept of Bayesian estimation, credibility interval, and Bayesian test.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Course Teaching Evaluation. To be conducted during the last two weeks of lectures.
• E-mail communications with the instructor.
• Performance in test/examination/essay/presentation. Assessment of what has been achieved by the students.
courses.required_readings: Hogg, Tanis, and Zimmerman (2015). Probability and Statistical Inference, 9th,. Pearson. (Chapters 5 to 9)
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Actuarial Mathematics for Long-Term Insurance
courses.description: After completing this course, students are expected to be familiar with the single decrement model in life contingencies. They would be able to formulate insurance and annuity benefits as random variables and perform calculations based on appropriate mortality assumptions. They would also be able to calculate premium and reserve under for simple products.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, students are expected to be familiar with the single decrement model in life contingencies. They would be able to formulate insurance and annuity benefits as random variables and perform calculations based on appropriate mortality assumptions. They would also be able to calculate premium and reserve under for simple products.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Survival Distributions and Life Tables
- Time-until-death and age-at-death random variables in both discrete and continuous forms; survival distributions; force of mortality; life table functions; random and deterministic survivorship group; introduction of recursion formulae; assumptions for fractional age; analytical laws of mortality; select and ultimate table

2. Life Insurance
- Life insurances with different protection and time of benefit payment provisions; statistical properties of present-value of benefit random variables for different life insurances; portfolio of life insurance

3. Life Annuities
- Life annuities with different payment structures; statistical properties of present-value of annuity payment random variables for different life annuities

4. Benefit Premiums
- Premium principles; statistical properties of insurers loss random variables; fully continuous, fully discrete and semi-continuous benefit premiums

5. Reserves
- Benefit reserve; gross premium reserve
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Course Teaching Evaluation. To be conducted during the last two weeks of lectures.
• E-mail communications with the instructor.
• Performance in test/examination/essay/presentation. Assessment of what has been achieved by the students.

courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Actuarial Mathematics for Short-Term Insurance
courses.description: The course aims to introduce students to severity models and frequency models and how they are used in short-term insurance coverages.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, students are expected to be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of: (a) Pricing and Reserving for Short-Term Insurance Coverages; and (b) the characteristics of and uses for commonly used severity, frequency, and aggregate models.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic to be covered:

(a) for severity models:
• Calculate moments and percentiles.
• Identify the role of scale and shape parameters in continuous models.
• Recognize classes of distributions and their relationships.
• Characterize distributions by existence of moments.

(b) for frequency models:
• Identify the role of parameters for the (a,b,0) class of distributions.
• Recognize the (a,b,0) class of distributions and their relationships.
• Perform calculations for the (a,b,0) class of distributions.
• Identify appropriate distributions for a given application.

(c) for aggregate risk models:
• Define collective and individual risk models and calculate their mean and variance.
• Use the log-normal or normal approximation to approximate the aggregate distribution.

(d) for risk measures:
• Calculate Value at Risk and Tail Value at Risk.
• Determine whether a given risk measure has certain desirable properties.

(e) for pricing and reserving
• Estimation of outstanding claims
• Ratemaking methods
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Course Teaching Evaluation. To be conducted during the last two weeks of lectures.
• E-mail communications with the instructor.
• Performance in test/examination/essay/presentation. Assessment of what has been achieved by the students.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Derivatives for Actuaries
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with knowledge in derivatives and their applications in pricing and reserving insurance products. Topics include financial forwards, futures, swaps, options; basic insurance strategies; parity relation; binominal option pricing models; the fundamental theorem of asset pricing; foundation of the Black-Scholes model; Brownian motion and stochastic calculus; derivation of Black-Scholes-Merton partial differential equation and Black-Scholes formula; volatility surface.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be familiar with the following about derivative securities:
• stocks, foreign exchange and futures as underlying assets
• the cash flow characteristics relating to various options and option strategies
• the binomial tree model, and be able to apply it to price European and American options
• the Black-Scholes model, and risk-neutral valuation methodology in continuous-time
• the principles of dynamic replication and hedging of financial derivatives
• risk analysis including decision trees, real options, and risk measures
• application of ordinary and exotic options in the context of actuarial-specific risk management
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics to be covered:
1. Introductory Derivatives- Underlying assets, forward and prepaid forward, options and related strategies
2. Binomial Option Pricing- One-period and multi-period trees
3. Black-Scholes Option Pricing- The Black-Scholes framework, properties of lognormal distribution, Greeks, dynamic hedging
4. Further Topics on Option Pricing- Exotic options, general properties of options
5. Actuarial Applications- Risk analysis including real options and risk measures; investment guarantees, other actuarial-related applications
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Course Teaching Evaluation. To be conducted during the last two weeks of lectures.
• E-mail communications with the instructor.
• Performance in test/examination/essay/presentation. Assessment of what has been achieved by the students.

courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Data Science for Insurance Analytics
courses.description: The course provides an overview of data science and insurance analytics, covering a broad selection of key challenges in and methodologies for working with big data. Topics include data collection, integration, management, modeling, analysis, visualization, prediction and informed decision making, as well as data security and data privacy. Students will acquire a working knowledge of insurance analytics through hands-on projects and case studies using R and Python (programme languages) with real financial and insurance datasets.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, students would be able to use statistical packages to fit, interpret and select various statistical models, and use these models for forecasting and prediction.
courses.course_syllabus:
Regarding to working with data:
• Identify structured, unstructured and semi-structured data types
• Identify the types of variables and terminology used in predictive modeling
• Evaluate the quality of appropriate data sources for a problem
• Identify the regulations, standards, and ethics surrounding predictive modeling and data collection

Models covered will include:
• Time Series Models
• Principal Component Analysis
• Cluster Analysis
• Tree-based Models

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Statistical Modelling for Insurance Analytics
courses.description: This course is devoted to insurance analytics by covering key concepts of statistical learning using R and Python programming languages. It provides the transition from mathematical statistics to insurance analytics and its applications. It covers the linear regression, generalized linear models and generalized additive models.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes: The goal of this course is to build on the training of students by developing the fundamentals of predictive modeling and providing corresponding applications in actuarial science, risk management and insurance. After completing this course, students should be able to apply the current statistical methodologies that prevail in actuarial science today.
courses.course_syllabus:
Models covered will include:
• Regression Model
• Generalized Linear Models

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Insurance and Risk Management
courses.description: In this course, insurance is treated as a major tool of risk management. The course covers risk management concepts; risk identification and measurement; property, net income, and liability loss exposures; analysis of life; property and liability insurance contracts; methods and problems of insurance pricing; and insurance regulation and public policy.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes: It is anticipated that after this course students know where to find resources to effectively manage risks (uncertain variability in future outcomes over a specified time period in a given situation) faced personally, in professional careers and as managers in business, government, and other organizations. The intent of the course is to encourage the development of analytical and decision-making skills within the context of risk management (the decision-making process by which adverse consequences of risk are minimized). Students will be learning how to identify and evaluate property, liability and human resource risks, and how to effectively apply the best combination of risk control and risk financing tools including insurance. Concepts of risk management precede the review of insurance, which is a major risk treatment method. Students are expected to be familiar with basic principles and practices of various insurance products.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part A: Basic Concepts in Risk Management & Insurance
• Risk and Its Treatment
• Insurance and Risk
• Introduction to Risk Management
• Enterprise Risk Management & Related Topics

Part B: Law and the Insurance Contracts
• Fundamental Legal Principles
• Analysis of Insurance Contracts

Part C: Life and Non-Life Insurance
• Life Insurance
• The Liability Risk

Part D: Insurance Company Marketing and Operations
• Types of Insurers and Marketing Systems
• Insurance Company Operations
courses.feedback_evaluation:

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Life Insurance
courses.description: This course covers laws and regulations of the life insurance, needs analysis, the life insurance contract, policy provisions and ownership rights, settlement options, pricing of life products, the underwriting function, medical insurance and long disability income policies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes: On completion of this part of the course, students should be able to explain the major issues in the operation of life insurance, understand the marketing and underwriting functions of life insurance, as well as the factors affecting the competition in life insurance industry. For health insurance, students should be able to explain the major health care issues in America and Hong Kong, understand the basic characteristics of individual major medical insurance, long-term care insurance, as well as disability-income plans. Students should be able to develop guidelines when purchasing individual health insurance. With knowledge in this course, students should be able to contribute to the debate on health care policy and retirement financing reform in Hong Kong.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics to be covered:
• Economics of life insurance
• Life & health insurance products
• Life insurance company organization and management
• Underwriting of life insurance
• Marketing of life insurance
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Course Teaching Evaluation. To be conducted during the last two weeks of lectures.
• E-mail communications with the instructor.
• Performance in test/examination/essay/presentation. Assessment of what has been achieved by the students.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Commercial Property and Liability Insurance
courses.description: This course examines risk management and operations of buyers and sellers of insurance. Basic principles and methods for assessing risks facing a non-insurance company and for selecting an optimal risk management programme are discussed in a broad insurance, finance, and statistical context. Because insurance is an important component of a risk management programme, the functional areas of providers of insurance (particularly property and casualty insurers) and the regulatory and market environment in which they operate are also discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, students should be able to perform: (a) comprehensive analysis of economic services, benefits, rates and rating theory, loss adjustment problems, legal theory factors, risk management concepts, loss prevention and transfer techniques and government regulation of public liability insurance, (b) comprehensive analysis of loss control and transfer techniques (including insurance), risk management concepts, loss adjustment and underwriting problems, and profitability/regulatory issues concerning the insurance industry.
courses.course_syllabus:
For liability insurance, topics include: medical malpractice, no-fault auto insurance, professional liability, workers' compensation, products liability and pollution liability.

For corporate property insurance, topics include: large-scale catastrophes (hurricanes and earthquakes), solvency, insurance coverages for property exposures, and loss control.

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Advanced Life Contingencies
courses.description: This course covers advanced concepts in long-term actuarial mathematics. Topics include determination of benefit premium and benefit reserves for life insurance and annuities; analysis of insurance loss random variables; theory of life contingencies for multiple lives.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, students are expected to be familiar with multiple decrement models, multiple state models, and multiple life models, and be able to perform pricing, valuation and profit calculation for these models. Students would be able to apply these models to a wide range of contemporary life insurance products. Students are expected to use spreadsheet programme to implement the models being studied.
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) Further analysis of reserve, including interim reserve, modified reserve, Hattendorf’s theorem and Thiele’s differential equation
(2) Multiple decrement models, with applications in the valuation and funding of pension plans
(3) Multiple state models, with relation disability and health products
(4) Multiple life models for independent and also dependent lives
(5) Premium, reserve and profit calculation for models in the above

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Loss and Survival Models
courses.description: This course covers advanced concepts in short-term actuarial mathematics. Topics include credibility theory; limited fluctuation; Bayesian; Buhlmann; Buhlmann-Straub; empirical Bayes parameter estimation; statistical inference for loss models; maximum likelihood estimation; effect of policy modifications; model selection.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Actuarial Science & Insurance Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, students are expected to be familiar with the statistical estimation and model selection principle of actuarial models used in general insurance. They would understand the framework of both classical and modern credibility theory as an approximation of Bayesian theory in insurance ratemaking. Students are expected to use spreadsheet programme and/or statistical packages to perform estimation of the models being studied.
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) Likelihood principle, including MLE, information matrix, confidence interval and confidence region
(2) Estimation, validation and selection of parametric loss models and frequency models for complete and incomplete data (due to policy modifications)
(3) Classical limited fluctuation credibility theory and its failure
(4) Concepts in Bayesian estimation
(5) Greatest accuracy credibility theory (including both Buhlmann and Buhlmann-Straub) and empirical Bayes estimation of credibility factors

courses.subject: FINA
courses.title: Independent Study
courses.description: Each student will be assigned a research project guided and supervised by the course instructor. It provides an opportunity for both the instructor and student to work together and thus enable them to have mutual understanding. It also aims to further the student's experience in undertaking research work. Upon completion of the course, the student is required to present his/her research report to fellow students and faculty.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Finance
courses.learning_outcomes: Students should learn how to conduct an independent research project. After completing this course, students should have acquired the following professional skills to deal with research questions in finance: (1) being familiar with the finance literature, especially the topics they are interested in; (2) applying appropriate econometric programming skills; (3) improving in written and presentation skills.
courses.course_syllabus: The topics are related to students' research interests and agreed by the supervisors.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Feedback for evaluation can be done through the individual meetings between the supervisor and the student.
courses.required_readings: Depending on the research topic, students are advised to read from a list of relevant journal papers.
